title: Explainer returns an array rather than an object
body:
I'm pretty puzzled by what's happening here and was hoping someone might shed some light on it.

We have an XGB Resgressor model saved as a JSON file.

We reload that model.

```
xgb_cv = XGBRegressor()
xgb_cv.load_model(model_name)
```

Which seems to work fine:

```
XGBRegressor(base_score=0.5, booster='gbtree', colsample_bylevel=0.7,
             colsample_bynode=0.7, colsample_bytree=0.9,
             enable_categorical=False, gamma=0.32, gpu_id=-1,
             importance_type='gain', interaction_constraints='',
             learning_rate=0.056, max_delta_step=0, max_depth=15,
             min_child_weight=1.64, missing=nan, monotone_constraints='()',
             n_estimators=500, n_jobs=1, num_parallel_tree=1, predictor='auto',
             random_state=42, reg_alpha=0, reg_lambda=1, scale_pos_weight=1,
             subsample=0.65, tree_method='hist', validate_parameters=1,
             verbosity=2)
```

I create an explainer object:

`explainer = shap.Explainer(xgb_cv)`

I calculate the SHAP values:

`shap_values = explainer.shap_values(X)`

This returns an ndarray, whereas I was expecting a "Explanation" object. Indeed, if I run the quick example at the start of the readme, it does produce an Explanation object for that dummy data. I don't understand why we're not getting the same. 

Any idea what's going on here? Because our shap_values are just an array, a lot of the plotting functions won't work on it. e.g. the waterfall plot complains that `'numpy.ndarray' object has no attribute 'base_values'`
